title: Transcriptome profiling after different kinds of stress in rodents
description: Stressful experiences elicit a variety of behavioral responses that range from increased alertness and vigilance to effects on cognitive processes. When stressors exceed individual threshold, such responses can lead to maladaptive behaviors manifested as depressive symptoms, anxious states or alterations in learning and memory. The biological response to stress is initiated by glucocorticoids and other stress-hormones that trigger a cascade of events that can ultimately lead to structural and functional alterations in the brain. These changes are mediated by changes at the level of gene expression, through the modulation of genes important for neural functions, such as synaptic plasticity, but also by modulation of epigenetic regulators. We are analyzing published RNA-seq transcriptomes obtained from the brain of mice exposed to different kinds of stress protocols, to generate a database of stress-related differentially expressed genes and to identify factors contributing to vulnerability or resistance to stress. These data will be relevant for identifying novel potential therapeutic targets for debilitating mental disorders such as depression and PTSD.
license: This work is licensed under a https://opensource.org/licenses/GPL-3.0.

meta.value: STRESS_MICE provides an easy access to a comprehensive database designed for storing, displaying and annotating Human Cell Line-specific gene fusion events detected from RNA-seq data.
